answer_html: If we choose \(-2 < x < 2\) we find that the left hand side of the inequality is positive, satisfying the inequality. Thus our domain is \(-2 < x < 2\), which written in interval notation is \(\displaystyle (-2, 2)\).
answer_latex:
If we choose $-2 < x < 2$ we find that the
left hand side of the inequality is positive, satisfying the inequality.
Thus our domain is $-2 < x < 2$, which written in interval notation is
$\displaystyle (-2, 2)$.
hints_html: Where is the function \(\ln (x)\) defined? What does that tell you about the argument (\(4 - x^2\)) of this function?
hints_latex:
Where is the function $\ln (x)$ defined? What does that tell you about
the argument ($4 - x^2$) of this function?
hints_raw: Where is the function <math>\ln (x)</math> defined?  What does that tell you about the argument (<math>4 - x^2</math>) of this function?
question: 8 (a)
sols_html:
The function \(\ln(x)\) is defined for all \(x > 0\). Therefore, in order for \(\ln(4 - x^2)\) to be defined, we need \(4 - x^2 > 0\). If we factor the left side of the inequality, we get

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle (2 - x)(2 + x) > 0\end{aligned}\]

For what values of x is this inequality true?

If \(x = 2\) or -2, then the left side of the inequality is zero, which is not allowed. So 2 and -2 cannot be part of our domain. Similarly, if \(x > 2\) or \(x < -2\), then the left side of the inequality will be negative, contradicting the inequality. So these values are also excluded from our domain. If we choose \(-2 < x < 2\) we find that the left hand side of the inequality is positive, satisfying the inequality. Thus our domain is \(-2 < x < 2\), which written in interval notation is \(\displaystyle (-2, 2)\).
sols_latex:
The function $\ln(x)$ is defined for all $x > 0$. Therefore, in order
for $\ln(4 - x^2)$ to be defined, we need $4 - x^2 > 0$. If we factor
the left side of the inequality, we get

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle (2 - x)(2 + x) > 0
\end{align*}

For what values of x is this inequality true?

If $x = 2$ or \emph{-2}, then the left side of the inequality is zero,
which is not allowed. So 2 and -2 cannot be part of our domain.
Similarly, if $x > 2$ or $x < -2$, then the left side of the inequality
will be negative, contradicting the inequality. So these values are also
excluded from our domain. If we choose $-2 < x < 2$ we find that the
left hand side of the inequality is positive, satisfying the inequality.
Thus our domain is $-2 < x < 2$, which written in interval notation is
$\displaystyle (-2, 2)$.
sols_raw:
The function <math>\ln(x)</math> is defined for all <math> x > 0</math>.  Therefore, in order for <math>\ln(4 - x^2)</math> to be defined, we need <math>4 - x^2 > 0</math>.  If we factor the left side of the inequality, we get

:<math>\displaystyle (2 - x)(2 + x) > 0</math>

For what values of x is this inequality true?  

If <math>x = 2</math> or ''-2'', then the left side of the inequality is zero, which is not allowed.  So 2 and -2 cannot be part of our domain.  Similarly, if <math>x > 2</math> or <math>x < -2</math>, then the left side of the inequality will be negative, contradicting the inequality.  So these values are also excluded from our domain.  If we choose <math>-2 < x < 2</math> we find that the left hand side of the inequality is positive, satisfying the inequality.  Thus our domain is <math>-2 < x < 2</math>, which written in interval notation is <math>\displaystyle (-2, 2)</math>.
statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = \ln\left(4-x^2\right)\end{aligned}\]

Find the domain of \(f\).
statement_raw:

:<math> \displaystyle
f(x) = \ln\left(4-x^2\right)
</math>

Find the domain of &fnof;.
